This game is hanging on by a thread and as a player that has played off and on since the days of Nexon it has seen better days. During the Nexon days the game was very popular with many channels because of it being part of Nexon. I played RedBana Audition for a little over 3 years off and on and the amount of people playing has dwindled down every year. This can be for a lot of reasons but it's biggest complaint I always heard was the lack of updates or extremely slow updates and losing licensing of good songs because they lack money. The days of having fun with your FAM (in game guild) and having Rivalry's with other FAM's are long over. The best you can hope for is to get a small group of friends you can play with otherwise the game is pretty boring alone. The game was good for its time back in 07 but the game is very outdated now, it's not going to get any better.

If you are looking for a Rhythm game to play there are better ones out there already like Mstar that are much more up to date not only with their character customization but songs as well. With the rate this game updates, it's many years behind it's origin server Korean Audition. What's the point of playing a Rhythm game with such a small and poor selection of songs. I definitely don't recommend this to any new players as the vast majority of players that play is out of Nostalgia and friends that still continue to play. Not only are their GM's corrupt and show favoritism to certain players in the community and ban those who they don't like, now they are even bribing players with in game money (Bana Cash) to give good reviews on here. As they know most players will be too lazy to do so or won't care as there no is reward involved. If this game was still good then why wouldn't the players happily support it without there being an in game reward involved?

You can really tell in the reviews who did it just for the Bana Cash reward, who knows if anyone will even get to see this with the massive flood of Bribed Reviews on the page already. Then those who would have gave it a good review despite there being a reward or not. Just a few points, I don't want to list everything.

Pros
- Fun if you manage to get a group of friends to play with.
- Pass the time being involved with the social network the game provides.
- Talk to people from different parts of the world.
- Various Rhythm modes from very easy to very hard
- Guitar Mode (Guitar Hero on the keyboard? Seems legit.)
- You can dress your character up in nice clothes

Cons
- A lot of drama
- Corrupt GM's
- Tournament's are dead or have hackers
- Slow updates
- Most of the community is rude (For a small player base that's disappointing.)
- All the nice clothes cost real $$$ and not all are permanent. (Permanent clothes cost roughly $10 each piece.)

I'm happy for the game that it managed to get on here but I think it's a bit too late. The game only continues to disappoint. You can compare it to something like MapleStory where they know the end is near for the game, they're just trying to milk as much money as they can from it before the game runs itself into the ground.

reviewText:
I've been a player of the game for about 8-9 years. (yes this game is that old(er) ) As I read a lot of the reviews below me, I've seen that many of the reviewers had come into the game with their mindset thinking that this was supposed to be DDR Online, or an OSU competitor. I can honestly tell you that this game is neither.

Audition Online is a heavy rhythm based online dancing game with heavy social aspects. Originally made in Korea, the game has very heavy K-pop culture references (fashion mall/ K pop dance moves), and many Korean songs. If you are annoyed by pop, electronic, or music that is in a foreign language, you most likely will pass on the game. There are enough English songs to pass for an American server, but a vast majority of songs are in Korean.

As said above, the Korean culture for the game is quite immense. The fashion mall (cash shop) is full of Korean Pop star references and clothing that would mostly make sense to the Kpop audience. The cash shop is completely optional. NOTHING in the cash shop will enhance your skills to the point of unfairness. There is a non-cash currency. (beats). These beats can be earned by playing with other players in the server. The selection of Beats items is quite small compared to the cash items, but there is enough to satisfy one's fashion sense to an extent.

The Gameplay for Audition is very different from DDR or OSU online. This is something that many new players fail to understand when they write the game off as a DDR clone. Players are given a combination of arrow keys that correspond to the 4 directional keys on the keyboard or the numpad, and must press those keys within the 4/4 metronome displayed, and then hit the space key once the bar reaches the 4/4 on the metronome. The metronome's speed is determined by each songs BPM. Often new players assume that they are really button mashing, but every arrow key combination is attached to a certain dance move. The fact is that this is just ONE of Audition's many different game modes.

Audition has roughly over 10 UNIQUE game modes, with about 15-20 different variations of certain game modes. Each mode has a different concept, a different way to play, and win. Some are team games, some are solo (story mode), and some are social modes (wedding, love party, club). I'd advise the DDR fans to start off with Beat Up mode which utilizes the players numpads using the keys (741/963) as the keys are tapped in direct relation to the rhythm, unlike Normal Mode" where only key combinations are pressed followed by the space bar at each fourth beat.

The game has a VERY steep learning curve. If you are prone to quitting easily

reviewText:
I've been playing Audition on and off for years, and as a fan of rhythm games, I adore it, but it comes with a fair share of problems.

The Good:
-it comes with a variety of game modes
-aside from a few UI enhancements and boost items, it's not pay to win
-there are plenty of cosmetic items you don't need cash to buy, BUT, you won't be able to get the Beats to buy them through regular play

The Bad:
-the game is old, looks old, and feels old
-there are a lot of bugs related to the game that have been around for //years//, so don't count on them getting them fixed
-expect frequent, or semi-frequent crashes
-there are no settings to customize the game's graphics or really, the game's anything, so there is very little to tweak in order to optimize the game (or even get it running decently...)
-some of the songs are explicit, so play with some headphones if other people are around

All in all, if you're willing to ignore a lot troubles, it's a fun game. But it's a risk, and if the game doesn't work with your setup for whatever reason, there's very little you can do to troubleshoot it. reviewText:
Plant watering every hour? Check.
Get to stare at your butt all game? Check.
Look ridiculous? Check.

Prior to this being released on Steam, I played this game from 2007 to roughly 2013 on different servers as well (American, Korean, Sea, European). While I have had a generally negative experience with the people I've met on this game, that's not what this review is about. I grew up with Audition, and although I don't play it anymore I have a general love of rhythm games and this one would easily make it in my top few.

Like with most rhythm games, there is a learning curve and it's pretty steap. That's not to say you can't get better at it without trying, but it takes some time. From my experience I've found that people who have prior experience with rhythm games or those who play instruments have an easier time adapting to the game as it requires both of your hands and a very basic grasp of rhythm, but in such a way that you have to keep up with multiple things at once, i.e. flashing lights, a moving camera (that you can adjust), your character (because yes, it can be distracting), the beat, inputing notes, and the difficulty level increasing throughout a song repeatedly, etc. The game also rewards you for your endeavours by giving you fancy, shiny medals and icons that stay with your character for all eternity (but you can turn them off).

The game offers multiple modes to try, from things similar to guitar hero or things that have a mixture of DDR and ITG elements, to NPC battles, team battles, couple battles (yes, you can get married!), and much more. Likewise, there's a large song bank that is constantly being updated. When I played it was rare to see a popular song on the radio on the game, but from what I've heard the songs are a little different than before. But, that doesn't make it a bad game. It actually makes it better if you consider the fact there are a multitude of genres. I actually discovered many artists that I  otherwise would've never known of.

Previously, I stated I didn't have a great experience with the people I met on the game. I think that is standard of most games, if not all. However, despite this, I do have to say the mods on the online forums and the GMs are always trying to interact with others, be helpful, and available. They could be friendly or simple and to the point, but it didn't matter to me as they offered their services frequently and in a timely manner. My experiences stem from not only being a senior on the forums but also with my interactions with them in game.

Overall, it's not Osu, DDR, or ITG. But that's not to say it isn't worth giving a shot. And if you like games where you can have an actual avatar that you can decorate, then that's a plus because many other rhythm games don't offer that. Much less a garden where you can harvest points for your couple rating..

reviewText:
my basis of recommendation of this game is based upon my positive experiences alone. with the way that this game is, you mileage may vary SIGNIFICANTLY.

i've been a player of this game off and on since the nexon beta eight years ago. it's come a long, long way since then, and especially so since it changed hands over to redbana several years ago. while it used to be clunky and quite far behind the korean servers, it catches up pretty well, now.

with the expansion of the game and the addition of quite a few game modes, this mmo is accessible to more players than ever before. there's a mode similar to guitar hero and one that's kind of like simon (yeah, the one with lights) plus a whole lot more; but if you're expecting something similar to stepmania, you're not going to find it here.

it should also be said that there is a learning curve to this game. some reviewers have called it too hard, but this isn't really a game you can pick up and be awesome at right away. as an experienced rhythm gamer coming in here 8 years ago, even i had some troubles adjusting to it.

with the game getting more exposure from being on steam, the barrier to entry isn't as terrible as it used to be. you'll very likely find some rooms with other new people, or find experienced players who are willing to help or be patient with you. do keep in mind that this game is a lot more strict on timing than other rhythm games out there (i'm looking at you, guitar hero).

i do have one gripe with the game that teeters me close to the point of not being able to recommend this game. the community desperately needs more adult players; and like any mmo, it's not that fun to play without friends. teenagers will have no problem finding friends within the game, but it's a little harder for people older than the US legal drinking age. if you want to pick up this game, i suggest bringing a friend along for the ride with you. you'll have a much better experience.

one thing to note is that i've experienced a significantly greater and consistent framerate coming back this time. if you're in the states and have played in the past, you'll notice almost zero issues with lag and surprise disconnects. provided your specs are fine (which they probably are), and you've got a decent internet connection, the game plays more or less flawlessly, now.

I've played for 8-9 years.Audition America is a westernized version of the original Korean and South east asia Audition server.This server embodies hiphop, latin , rock , alternative , edm, pop music and a few other sub-genres along with Korean songs to tie it all back to where the game started.  If you dont understand Korean like I do, you just get used to hearing the beats overtime and its still just as pleasant as English songs. As far as popularity (mainstream) songs, there are some but I learned to favor the ones I dont hear often on the radio. There are also a few player made songs as well. If you're willing to teach yourself a new method of rhtyhm to different songs , this is the game for you.

Upon entering , you will have to teach yourself how to navigate around the game if you dont see a guide for it on the forums, but people are always down to thelp you find your way if you ask in the lobby if you dont click on all the help icons on the screen.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game for over 9 years now. I can honestly say that this game is one of my favorite games of all time, if not purely for the social aspect.

This game is all about enjoying music, talking to others/making friends, enjoying improvement of your own skills, competing in tournaments or even attempting to date if you want to go that far.

For the gameplay part, there is an extreme amount of variety. You may only like certain modes and hate others, but you cannot say this game does not have variety and creativity in its game modes.

The main part of the game is simple, press arrow keys, once they are all pressed time space bar at the right time (The 4th beat of the music) and try to get perfect. Do this more than you opponent to win. The winning condition will vary, the keys will vary, there will be random missions asking you to do challanges, hell there are even modes for different instruments that you can buy (Think Guitar hero), but the basics of pressing keys to the beat of music will remain.

The social aspect is what really makes this game shine. You meet new people all the time, you talk all the time, you laugh, you talk about serious issues, you trash talk in a friendly manner, you gossip, join families (Guilds/Clans) you just relax. I have met so much life long friends in this game that I will never forget, no other game comes close.

Once you start playing and get past learning the game you will understand why people seem to continue to aply this game through years and years. It has just the right amount of challenge to keep you wanting to improve at all times.. While at the same is a game you can go on to vent, relax, play super casually and just have fun with other people/friends.

Both elements of the game are important, but the community really makes this game shine and stand the test of time. The most friendly gamers you will ever meet.

reviewText:
TLDR: Average age is 16-20. Try all the modes. Beatup = DDR, GuitarHero/Rockband=Guitar Mode Check out the Redbana Forums.
After all the 8-9 ish years I've played it, Audition Online  is a great game!  Years ago, at first when I tried it, it took a long time to get used to, but I cant stress this enough.Try to explore all the modes! I didnt do so hot in some modes but I really excel in others! The mode most similar to DDR is Beat Up and Block Beat! The most most similar to Guitar Hero/ Rockband is the Guitar Mode (of course)! If you would like to enhance your gameplay (with 8k,C9 and beat up for example), you will need a numpad.The game really varies more than the normal mode you see upon the tutorial (in my opinion it's outdated and could use an upgrade to go over all the other modes). .You can look at a glimpse of them with the video provided. You can see how to play modes in depth (just a mini guide) by pressing f12 in the game room.

Community: As far as the community goes , it's nice!  The age range is about ages 16-20.  In-game, most high levels would seem intimidating to approach at first, but they are willing to lend a helping hand if you need to (like myself xD) ! You see familiar faces if you stick around for a bit! There are times where the game would show more locked rooms than unlocked but it depends on the times you're on. I know most players are fluent in English (the most prominent) but a few circles do speak fluent Spanish,German, Viet and Portugese which I learned quite a bit for my language skills LOL. You can also join FAMs and play in FAM battles together which is nice .There are suspicions of people hacking but the hacking doesn't occur as often as it used to be with Nexon. A huge huge majority of the population has leveled up on their own without the usage of hacks and bots. Any that were caught doing so have been banned. If there are any suspicions of hacks it would be done privately and submitted in a ticket.

Music: If you're into different styles well be prepared because there are a lot of them. The genres do vary but expect to hear Korean and Spanish. And it's not really all one list for every mode you play. Some modes like ballroom will have its own set of songs and guitar mode will as well. I find that songs suitable to fit the types of modes is a well thought out process instead of sitcking to 1 list for everything.

Game Currency:  BEATS are rather difficult to acquire when you don't have a ring/garden to work with. You would have to depend on Battle Parties which are fun but they're time consuming before you can spend your beats in mall on the higher items.  Time it would take to get 1,000,000 beats in battle party would take about 30 min - an hour depending on the amount you choose. With a couple ring and doing garden, you can get around 2-3 million beats in a day without having to play any games. Another thing I like about it is you can get coupons for your CASH items at anytime using time box.

Tournaments: As far as tournaments go, most of them start but there are a few that dont due to the lack of players entering the tournament that day. The current number required for a tournament to start should be fixed. That's really my only issue I've had with the game.

There is a forum website : forums.redbana.com that players can communicate on about the inner workings of the game if an error occurs,  BANA CASH from GM and player hosted events and a graphics/drawings to show your creative side!

TIP: To run Audition in windows mode, you'll have to download the original client for now or try downloading the Audition Xpatcher http://forums.jordantrudgett.com/viewtopic.php?f=1&t=31 and click run Audition. Its always been the alternative patch to the original one for a few years now. Surely its not through steam, but it will save you time having to redownload the original redbana site patcher until they make a windowed mode for steam.

Hope to see you guys soon! -Badass

reviewText:
I've been playing Audition on and off since 2007 when it was released in NA. (The original Korean version is over 10 years old now!)

It hasn't aged well, and the lack of settings (in-game and out) is a pretty big issue which is unlikely to ever be addressed, unfortunately. You don't play Audition, Audition plays you! Oh, but if you're looking for the in-game volume settings, press ctrl + S when you're in game. Solves everything, right? No???

I don't want to make this too long winded, so in short:

- If you like rhythm games definitely do give it a try, there are a lot of modes so there's bound to be something for you

- The learning curve is steep and the in-game tutorial isn't great. It's frustrating, and you have to be prepared for that

- On a similar note, it's extremely difficult to master, so you're constantly able to challenge yourself (...and others)

- Do not play alone!! Audition is a social game, plus being a noob on your own is not fun and will probably make you quit

- Despite being free to play it does obviously have a cash shop, but you can play 99% of the game no problem without ever spending anything. Most of the benefits of the cash shop are only cosmetic. The rest won't matter to you unless you get really into the game

I'm not going to lie and say Audition is a perfect game because it most certainly is not. But if you enjoy rhythm games and you are looking for something new I do recommend trying it!

reviewText: Audition is one of the few games that I always come back to play whenever I have free time. There are a variety of modes to choose from and many people prefer certain modes over others. If you don't like one mode, it's perfectly fine because it all comes down to personal preference. There are many more to choose from but keep in mind that the game itself requires effort and time to see improvement. Most players are well-rounded/decent in all modes because they are willing to learn and try most of the modes. As a dance-related and rhythm based game, there is certainly a competing aspect to Audition. The game is set-up in such a way that allows one to increase/decrease the level of difficulty accordingly. For instance, the speed (BPM) of a song and the level of a mode affects how easy/hard it is to play. Generally, the game is not all about the competition, there are also social aspects of the game which enable players to have fun and socialize with people from around the world, not only limited to North America. This game is definitely recommended to people who love:-Dolling up your pixels. This game has a variety of clothing and you can work your magic with it. They mostly implement Korean-based fashion, so the style will seem flashy and over the brim.

reviewText:
PROS

- Fun casual rhythm game that doesn't take too long to learn as long as you stick with slower songs at first
- Provides challenge at faster/harder songs once you get used to easier ones
- Tutorial is not too long and effectively gives you the basics
- Lots of people to play with
- Nice community for the most part, friendly people
- Lots of rooms for newbies most of the time, and it's easy to make your own room if there isn't
- Lots of fun game modes (Club Dance is one of my favorites so far)
- Lots of songs (there are a lot of songs about sex and drugs, but there are good songs in there as well, and most of them are at least catchy)

CONS

- Graphics are blocky and outdated and cause slight lag at times (not that bad or even frequent, though, but it does affect gameplay)
- Getting beats is slow, and you can't get much if you don't have a lot, can't complete missions, or can't afford Bana Cash
- Some people did ban me from a room without explanation
- Missions pop up randomly and often have strange conditions (10 perfects or LESS) and show up even for beginners who couldn't do them

Overall, this game has been very fun so far despite its shortcomings. It needs a graphical update and a revamp of the missions system, but that's about it. If you like casual rhythm games, I would check this out.

As people stated before, this game leans more toward the social aspect than skills and game play. It's more fun to play with friends rather than alone. I made many new friends a few years ago and still talk to some of them today.
The music playlist is pretty alright, songs are worth playing but not worth enough to put on your everyday music playlist.
There are plenty of modes to play, you don't have to stick to one. There is 4-key, 8-key, team choreography, couple games like ballroom or couple mode, beat up, etc. I really love Crazy 8k and beat rush, those modes are the only ones that interests me.
It takes a lot of practice to get good at a mode. It requires persistence and determination. Newbies can get discouraged easily because they can't match up to the people who have been playing many years. Practice is key.
You don't have to be single anymore! You can get married, do love parties, gather hearts by couple garden, and even nurture a baby!
I suggest people should find a fam or family. It is similar to a guild compared to other games. It's really nice to see people bond as a family. You can fam battle or go against other fams to see which fam's skills is better.
The mall is full of super cute clothing, but you have to spend real money in order to look fabulous.
The community is pretty nice and helpful. The community of the forums, in my opinion, is better than the game community. I spend more time on there than the game itself.
There are negatives to this game regarding the updates and management, but I won't share them here.


Hit me up if you're interested in talking to me or have any questions regarding the game. : )

Put short and sweet, this game is very, very addicting.


A bit of a personal story:
I started playing in 2007 when Audition was still under Nexon and remember playing it for hours upon hours. Come 2009, I quit because of technical issues and thought I would never play the game again. I honestly completely forgot about the game under one day in 2014 I somehow heard a song that I remembered was from Audition. Overcome by an extreme sense of nostalgia, I searched up the game, was surprised to find out that it still existed, and re-downloaded it immediately. I expected to only dabble in the game for a short while to satisfy my nostalgia, but it was too late--I was addicted again, and have been very active ever since.


Now why is this game so addicting? Well, there's a variety of possible reasons, since there's so many things about the game that could make it addicting.

The most common reason would be the community. Many of the active players have been playing this game for years, so they know each other quite well. The game doesn't have many players when you compare it to more popular games, but that makes this game have a close-knit community. Even if you never talk to some people, if you play at least semi-actively you can recognize the IGNs of various other players. reviewText:
Alright, time for an actual review of this game as of 2015.

This game is pretty fun, once you get the hang of it. It has one of the sharpest learning curves that I've come across, and easily the most difficult multiplayer rhythm game out there to pick up and play.

The community is pretty small, and overall pretty nice.

As of now, songs are plentiful, but they're mostly underground/mainstream EDM and Korean music.

There is only one p2w aspect to the game and even then nobody uses it because it helps very little. It's also disabled in any competitive modes, which is great.

This game as one fatal flaw - it's a game from 2006 that hasn't aged well at all. No graphics options in-game (uses all settings from your drivers, and even then it only picks up drivers from nvidia cards because this game uses OpenGL). 1024x768 locked resolution. Windows 8.1 compatibility issues out of the box (issue with a certain KB update). Anti-cheat issues with certain programs. The list goes on and on. I can't see a typical new user with no experience with these types of games genuinely enjoying Audition when theres a lot of options that PC gamers expect to see with any game blatantly missing.

If you can deal with those flaws, give Audition a try. Otherwise, Audition's sequel should be coming over to the West in a year or so (World In Audition). It is a MUCH better game, albeit having some minor differences that regular Audition players come to expect. If World In Audition came to Steam, I would wholeheartedly recommend it.

reviewText:
Honest review
I've been playing this game since Nexon (approx 7 years). This game has its pros and cons like any other game. I constantly find myself quitting and coming back to this game. I'm pretty sure a lot of players find themselves doing this. Even if we find this gaming extremely outdated or boring for some reason it always charms its way back into our desktops.

PROS:
* There are different types of modes for this rhythm based game that can be comparable to other games
* There is a now growing community, but even at its lowest of moments there are loyal players
* There are geniunely nice people in game (however of course there are bad ones as well)
* Story modes create a sense of togetherness by having other players play together and help another out
* There are daily tournaments
* A large selection of clothing in the mall
* There are many events held for players that are posted on both the Facebook page and Redbana forum
* You can get married and have level up rings to look forward to
* It is a social game
* New songs and cash items come every so often
* A very unique community (people are very strange on Audition, in a good way!)
* There are also FAMs (similar to clans or guilds) which can also battle other ones (with rankings)
* Friendly GMs and community advisors

CONS:
* Not the best songs out there compared to other Audition servers and are not appropriate at times
* Doesn't make sense that cuss words are censored in games but are in the songs
* Even with XTRAP software there are still hackers
* Sometimes it seems like there is favourtism in the game
* This game costs a lot of money to look fabulous (x8 the one week item is the cost to indefinite) I've personally spent over two grand on this game and have been hacked on one of my accounts recently. It's asisine that you can sell indefinite cash items for beats, this is just asking for hackers to make people miserable.  Ring breaking is also tragic, but I won't get into that
* If you don't have friends to play with or have trouble making friends then the game itself can get pretty boring
* The graphics are outdated and we cannot change settings other than volume control by using CTRL + S
* Does not properly support Windows 8 and 8.1 users
* AUDI DRAMA (you'll know it when you see it!)

But overall, I have always recommended this game to my friends to play with me for fun. It's always nice to go hiatus and come back to meet people from the past to reminisce. We don't play for the quality of the game, we play because of the memories we make! The game is also fun too, if you're good at it  LOL

Tech support is alright, what can you expect from a free to play game that's trying to survive. It's finally having a second wind though because of the new Steam players!

I hope this was helpful. Enjoy your time in our Audition world if you choose to join us all!

reviewText:
Honest review
I've been playing this game since Nexon (approx 7 years). This game has its pros and cons like any other game. I constantly find myself quitting and coming back to this game. I'm pretty sure a lot of players find themselves doing this. Even if we find this gaming extremely outdated or boring for some reason it always charms its way back into our desktops.

PROS:
* There are different types of modes for this rhythm based game that can be comparable to other games
* There is a now growing community, but even at its lowest of moments there are loyal players
* There are geniunely nice people in game (however of course there are bad ones as well)
* Story modes create a sense of togetherness by having other players play together and help another out
* There are daily tournaments
* A large selection of clothing in the mall
* There are many events held for players that are posted on both the Facebook page and Redbana forum
* You can get married and have level up rings to look forward to
* It is a social game
* New songs and cash items come every so often
* A very unique community (people are very strange on Audition, in a good way!)
* There are also FAMs (similar to clans or guilds) which can also battle other ones (with rankings)
* Friendly GMs and community advisors

CONS:
* Not the best songs out there compared to other Audition servers and are not appropriate at times
* Doesn't make sense that cuss words are censored in games but are in the songs
* Even with XTRAP software there are still hackers
* Sometimes it seems like there is favourtism in the game
* This game costs a lot of money to look fabulous (x8 the one week item is the cost to indefinite) I've personally spent over two grand on this game and have been hacked on one of my accounts recently. It's asisine that you can sell indefinite cash items for beats, this is just asking for hackers to make people miserable.  Ring breaking is also tragic, but I won't get into that
* If you don't have friends to play with or have trouble making friends then the game itself can get pretty boring
* The graphics are outdated and we cannot change settings other than volume control by using CTRL + S
* Does not properly support Windows 8 and 8.1 users
* AUDI DRAMA (you'll know it when you see it!)

But overall, I have always recommended this game to my friends to play with me for fun. It's always nice to go hiatus and come back to meet people from the past to reminisce. We don't play for the quality of the game, we play because of the memories we make! The game is also fun too, if you're good at it  LOL

Tech support is alright, what can you expect from a free to play game that's trying to survive. It's finally having a second wind though because of the new Steam players!

I hope this was helpful. Enjoy your time in our Audition world if you choose to join us all!

reviewText:
okay so the graphics and animations are not the greatest, but what would you expect from a game released 2 Apr, 2007? there arent many up to date songs, apart from two Panic! at the disco songs (one exclusive to the games bgm track list) but the songs available are still pretty good.

hard core players of the game are ruthless, and dont go easy on new players. not many do, but you do find the odd few who talk you through things and end up having conversations with you.

there are two 'main' modes to the game. Dancing and playing guitar.

the guitar gameplay is much like, as you would expect, guitar hero. except, your reactions need to be almost perfect when hitting each button or youre done for basically. it hasnt got the best responce time but is still fun to play. theres only one guitar game to play, so there isnt much variation to the mode. just play guitar, earn exp and beats. rinse and repeat.

the other main mode is dancing, which is by far the most popular part of the game. dancers taking up at least 99% of the games community. its difficult at first, but the only controls used are the arrows and space bar. (unless you change it up a little and do some kind of couple/club dance where you use f1 f2 and f3)

this game is fun and challenging, no doubt about it. graphics are not what make a game, it works just fine and just about anyone can play.

reviewText:
I have history with this game, before it was available on Steam, Before Redbanna ran it, I played back since Nexon and it's a game I come back to time and time again.

I've met so many different kinds of people via Audition, and it's been around for a lot of rough years for me, honestly it probably helped me get through them, yes it is a game that people can arguably say requires little to no skills because yes it mainly consists of arrowkeys and the spacebar (and watching an anime-like figure dance on your screen, sometimes in unrealistic form- like when in s.b.boy the character drops through the floor boards or defies gravity haha), but I can tell anyone that although I have spent hours- years on this game, that I have nowhere near mastered it. Course it helps that I take breaks every once in a while when life catches up to me but there's always something to do on there. Like some of the comments have mentioned, Beside having a variety of 'modes', Audition is also a hotspot for meeting people. I have come across many great online friends over the years whom I would have never met if it weren't for Audition. So I am eternally grateful so to speak, and yes I would be devastated to learn one day that I were no longer able to play- I mean yeah I'd survive, but to lose the option of being able to get on once more- ouch. Like I said, it's a part of me!

BASICALLY, if you're into music, button-mashing, somewhat decent to bad graphics depending on how you look at it, and random amusing conversations with strangers who don't necessarily have to be strangers for long go ahead and try it out, DON'T expect too much from it- just have fun.  :) Just my opinion, everyone is allowed to have their own!

Wow, it's been a while.

Let me start off by saying that if this is you're playing this game for your first time, you will be thoroughly confused. I played Audition several years ago when it was owned by the company Nexon. Since then, they've given ownership to RedBana. This transition, however, was NOT for the better. When I played the game a while back, it was about skill and meeting others who could help you through challenges and such. Now, the servers are filled with password-locked lobbies that have one or two people in them. Also, there's mainly ONE server to even play on. During Nexon days, there were several. It's a shame to see this game going down such a bad path. It had potential.

Unless you want to TRY to relive some nostalgia and then be dissapointed, I would suggest staying away from Audition Online. Trust me, you're not missing out.

1. Position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)

Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.

Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.

Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans.
